resources.string: Math Quest
GameActivity
StudyActivity
ScoreGameActivity
Question 1 - At the castle moat:
You finally reach the castle and see that it is surrounded by an alligator infested moat.\nYou notice a number pad, with a hint saying \"The password is 2A.\", signed by Lord Hexadecimal.
You finally reach the castle and see that it is surrounded by an alligator infested moat.\nYou notice a number pad, with a hint saying \"The password is 2A.\", signed by Lord Hexadecimal.
2A converted from hexadecimal to decimal is:
Question 2 - The Jester at the gate:
The passcode was correct! At the end of the moat, Calcebra\'s jester blocks your way. He draws a card at random from a deck of cards and asks you to guess its suit.

Well, you got the passcode wrong so you resorted to swimming past the alligators. That was not a good idea.\n\nAs you make it to the other side of the moat, Calcebra\'s jester blocks your way. He draws a card at random from a deck of cards and asks you to guess its suit.
Assuming a deck of cards has 52 cards, and 13 of each suit, what is the percentage probability that the card\'s suit is spades? (ex. 60 percent would be 0.60)
Question 3 - Enter the courtyard:

The jester is amazed at your mathematical prowess and lets you through. You walk into a courtyard filled with numerous trees. Suddenly, the trees come alive and ensnare you with their branches. A magical vine hands you a scroll with another problem to solve, seemingly unwilling to let you go until you provide it with an answer.

The jester looks disappointed, then attacks you. Despite being hurt a bit from the fight, you manage to subdue him and progress into a courtyard filled with numerous trees. Suddenly, the trees come alive and ensnare you with their branches. A magical vine hands you a scroll with another problem to solve, seemingly unwilling to let you go until you provide it with an answer. The druid of the forest is choosing three of the ten trees to animate into treants.
How many ways can you pick three members of a group of ten if order does not matter?
Question 4 - The Grand Hall:

The druid likes your answer and lets you go. You find your way to the Grand Hall. The hall is dark, but there is a flickering circuit beside you. The button does not work, but there is a dial and a formula to calculate the voltage that the circuit should receive.

The druid did not like your answer, and you hurt yourself when you use your knife to cut yourself free. At the end of the courtyard, you find your way to the Grand Hall. The hall is dark, but there is a flickering circuit beside you. The button does not work, but there is a dial and a formula to calculate the voltage that the circuit should receive. Lightly glowing, the formula reads:
The circuit in front of you takes a maximum voltage \"the limit as x approaches two, of 8 – 3x + 12x^2\". What voltage should the circuit receive?
Question 5 - The Dungeon Entrance:

You hear a resonating hum, and a solitary light turns on above one of the doors indicating that it is the one you need. However, it seems to be locked and the only way to open it is to solve the riddle you find engraved around the door frame.

You fumble with the circuit to no avail, and resort to finding the door manually. You stumble and fall a few times but eventually find the correct one labeled "DUNGEON ENTRANCE". However, it seems to be locked and the only way to open it is to solve the riddle you find engraved around the door frame.
\"I am a graph with four vertices and six edges. Can I exist?\"\n\nAnswer 1 for yes or 0 for no.
Question 6 - Freeing the Princess:

The door hears your answer, and seemingly alive, swings upon with a ceremonious thud. You enter the dungeon and find Princess Trig held by Calcebra. You immediately notice that something is not right about the scene in front of you.

The door does not open. You smash at it with your fists and, seemingly hurt, the door swings upon with a ceremonious thud. However, you receive a few splinters in your hand. You progress through the dungeon and find Princess Trig held by Calcebra. You immediately notice that something is not right about the scene in front of you. Everything seems to be upside down.
Let the image in front of you be represented by a 2-D vector in the form of (x, y). What do you multiply the y-coordinate by in order to reflect the image about the x-axis?
Question 7 – Past The Illusion:

You flip the image in front of you and discover that it is an illusion. You feel the floor under you give way, and you are able to roll as you fall to the level below you. There is a golden shield in front of you, but it\'s locked behind a combination.

While you struggle to flip the image in front of you, the floor under you gives way and you fall. You suffer a few bruises. You see a golden shield in front of you, but it\'s locked behind a combination.
How many possible permutations exist for the letters in the word \“SHIELD\”?
Question 8 – Another Useful Tool:

Realizing that 720 combinations is too much, you search around the room for another way to retrieve the shield. You find a lever, pull it, and retrieve the shield from the wall. You discover a sword behind it with the same locking mechanism.

You figure that there aren\'t too many combinations to enter, and you start guessing. By the time you are finished, your fingers become sore. You unlock the shield and discover a sword behind it with the same locking mechanism.
How many possible permutations exist for the letters in the word \“SWORD\”?
Question 9 – Three Paths

You unlock the sword with ease and press on. You discover three paths in front of you, but there\'s a map. The map is given in the format of a binary search tree, with the way out given in the right child.

Your fingers become raw as you enter all the possible permutations manually, and eventually guess the answer and take the sword. You discover three paths in front of you, but there\'s a map. The map is given in the format of a binary search tree, with the way out given in the right child.
The binary search tree in front of you has three nodes consisting of 1, 4, and 7. The root is 4. The right child of the root has what value?
Question 10 - Three Paths, Part II
You take the path labeled 7 and gleefully press on. You find another three paths, and they diverge in the same fashion. However, the root of the tree is indicated as the right way out.

You are not convinced that your answer is particularly correct after running into a swarm of stinging bees. After receiving a few painful stings, you double back to take the path labeled with 7 instead. You find another three paths, and they diverge in the same fashion. However, the root of the tree is indicated as the right way out.
The binary search tree in front of you has three nodes consisting of 78, 32, and 45. The left child has a value of 32. Which number must its parent be?
Question 11 - The Final Three Paths

You take the correct path, so it would seem. It leads to what looks like the exit, until you walk into an illusory wall. With a hurt head, you double back and head onto another path. The final three doors await. The answer is given to you with a binary search tree\'s root.

You are not sure which path to follow and take the one directly in front of you. It leads to what looks like the exit, until you walk into an illusory wall. With a hurt head, you double back and head onto another path. The final three doors await. The answer is given to you with a binary search tree\'s root.
The binary search tree in front of you has three nodes consisting of 2, 66, and 5. What number must the root be?
Question 12 - Tower Ascension I:

Upon entering door 5, you reach the base of the stairs to Calcebra\'s Tower. Each of the stairs are guarded by the Algebrains, floating inquisitive creatures that prevent you from passing unless you answer their questions. The first Algebrain asks you:

You are unsure that your answer is correct, and you open all three doors. One of the doors electrocutes you however. After opening door 5, you see the base of the stairs to Calcebra\'s Tower. Each of the stairs are guarded by the Algebrains, floating inquisitive creatures that prevent you from passing unless you answer their questions. The first Algebrain asks you:
\"What is the dot product of the vectors (7, 6) and (5, 1)?\"
Question 13 - Tower Ascension II:
The first Algebrain likes your response and allows you to pass. You ascend the stairs, and the next Algebrain asks you:
The first Algebrain shakes, and explodes into a puff of blinding smoke. You suffer a small headache. You ascend the stairs, and the next Algebrain asks you:
What is the dot product of the vectors (3, 3) and (0, 8)?
Question 14 - Tower Ascension III:
Correct! The Algebrain lets you pass. The next floor has a new creature called a Trigonometron. It seems to work in the same fashion as the Algebrains. It asks:
Incorrect! The Algebrain explodes into a puff of ground pepper, causing you to sneeze uncontrollably. The next creature, a Trigonometron, seems to work in the same way as the Algebrains. It asks:
Evaluate sin(pi/2).
Question 15 - Tower Ascension IV:
Amused it would seem, the Trigonometron allows you to pass. The next one asks:
Disappointed, the Trigonometron attacks you with an electric stun rod. You collapse convulsing and pass out, and upon waking it is gone. You proceed to the next one, and it asks:
Evaluate sin(2 * pi)
Question 16 - Tower Ascension V:
You begin to feel the fatigue of climbing the tower, but press on. The next Trigonometron asks:

You begin to feel the fatigue of climbing the tower. Getting the answer wrong, you are not surprised when the Trigonmetron shocks you with a stun rod. After passing out and waking up, you proceed to the next Trigonmetron\'s question:
Evaluate cos(pi / 3)
Question 17 - Tower Ascension VI:
Happy with your answer, the Trigonometron allows you to proceed to the next floor and the next question.
Unhappy with your answer, the Trigonometron shocks you with its stun rod before leaving, allowing you to proceed to the next floor and the next question.
Given the following equation, what value must be in the blank in order for the equation to represent the surface area of a sphere?\nA = __ * pi * r^2
Question 18 - Tower Ascension VII:
The Trigonometron does not leave, but instead opens a door beside it labeled \"To Calcebra\'s Chambers\". You proceed through the door, but there is a gate with a riddle on it. It reads:

The Trigonometron does not leave, but instead points you to a door beside it labeled \"To Calcebra\'s Chambers\". You reach to open the door, but the Trigonometron shocks you with a stun rod and you pass out. Upon waking, you find yourself in the room with a gate and a riddle on it. It reads:
For a function to be considering strictly increasing, what value must the derivative (f\'(x)) be greater than?
Question 19 - To Calcebra\'s Chambers I:
The gate opens and you proceed. Another gate appears around the corner, and you must unlock it with another answer to its riddle.
The gate does not open, and you swing at it with your sword. Your arm gets sore, but it opens. Another gate appears around the corner, and you must unlock it with another answer to its riddle.
An even number can be written in the form of __ * n. What value goes in the blank?
Question 20 - To Calcebra\'s Chambers II:
The gate opens and you proceed. The next riddle is:
The gate does not open, and you bash it open with your shield. Your shoulder becomes bruised, but you are able to open the gate. The next riddle is:
An odd number can be written in the form of 2n + __. What value goes in the blank?
Question 21 - Count Modulo\'s Barracks I

You find yourself past the gates, and you find that you have stepped into a room of sleeping soldiers under Count Modulo, Calcebra\'s master of war. You must disarm the alarms before proceeding. The alarms are protected by the following:

You strain yourself forcing opening the gates, and you find that you have stepped into a room of sleeping soldiers under Count Modulo, Calcebra\'s master of war. You must disarm the alarms before proceeding. The alarms are protected by the following:
Evaluate 17 % 3.
Question 22 - Count Modulo\'s Barracks II
Well done. You discover that there is another element to the alarm.
The alarm seems to be ready to trigger, but you discover another element of the alarm. Perhaps you have another chance.
Evaluate 123 % 1.
Question 23 - Count Modulo\'s Barracks III
Correct again! A confirmation on the alarm appears, followed by a final verification problem:
Things do not look good. A confirmation on the alarm appears, followed by a final verification problem:
Evaluate 11 % 7.
Question 24 - Inner Sanctum I:

You have prevented the alarm from going off and you proceed into Calcebra\'s inner sanctum. You hear a faint voice that resembles Princess Trig\'s. It seems that the voice is trying to tell you the password for the next door.

The alarm goes off. The soldiers awaken and rush you down, but you manage to endure their assault as you run into the next room and shut the door behind you. You hear a faint voice that resembles Princess Trig\'s. It seems that the voice is trying to tell you the password for the next door.
Find the number that belongs in the following sequence: 0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21, __ , …
Question 25 - Inner Sanctum II:
The door opens, and you listen for the voice again for the next door. The voice says:
The door does not open, but the door swings open as the soldiers behind you pour through. You take a bit of abuse as you rush through and close the door behind you again.
What is the least common multiple of 4, 5, 6, and 7?
Question 26 - Inner Sanctum III:
The door opens, and the voice speaks again:
The door does not open and the onslaught of soldiers hurts you as you force your way through the door. The voice speaks again:
What is the least common multiple of 3, 5, and 11?
Question 27 - Calcebra\'s Final Tests:

You enter through the door and are met by Calcebra and Princess Trig. She does not look particularly flustered, yet you rush to attack Calcebra. He parries your attack with a mathematical protection incantation. To push through, you must solve it:

You enter through the door despite the onslaught of soldiers. You are hurt a bit. Past the door you are finally met by Calcebra and Princess Trig. She does not look particularly flustered, yet you rush to attack Calcebra. He parries your attack with a mathematical protection incantation. To push through, you must solve it:
What is the 4-bit binary representation of the decimal number 8?
Question 28 - Calcebra\'s Final Tests:
You break his spell, but he casts another one right after it:
You opt to swing at his magical barrier with your sword, but you hurt yourself in the process. He refreshes his spell with the following question:
What is the 4-bit binary representation of the decimal number 13?
Question 29 - Calcebra\'s Final Tests:
Impressed with your mathematical knowledge, Calcebra conjures up a final spell for you to break:
You smash the barrier open with shield, slightly damaging yourself in the process. Calcebra looks nervous as he conjurers up a final spell:
Binary numbers are part of a base-x numeral system. What is the value of x?
Question 30 - Calcebra\'s Final Tests:
As the barrier disappears, and the last of Calcebra\'s energy is spent, the Princess yells out that you can vanquish him by answering the following question:
You headbutt the barrier causing some slight discomfort and some lost brain cells. The Princess yells out that you can vanquish him by answering the following question:
The decimal numbers we use every day are part of a base-z numeral system. What is the value of z?
A homogeneous equation is defined as a system that can be written as Ax = ?
What is the maximum rank of a matrix with 2 rows and 4 columns?
What is the maximum rank of a matrix with 5 rows and 3 columns?
Two vectors are orthogonal if their dot product is equal to what number?
What is the nullity of a matrix with 7 pivot variables and 4 free variables?
f(x) = 23x^2 + 7x + 8. What is f(3)?
f(x) = 5x^2 + x + 13. What is f(4)?
f(x) = 8x^2 + 11x + 7. What is f(2)?
g(x) = x^2 + 3x + 2. What is g(3)?
What is the nullity of a matrix with 9 pivot variables and 2 free variables?
The determinant of a matrix A is 3. The determinant of a matrix B is 4. The determinant of a matrix C where C = AB is what?
The determinant of a matrix A is 8. The determinant of a matrix B is 9. The determinant of a matrix C where C = AB is what?
The determinant of a matrix A is 20. The determinant of a matrix B is 2. The determinant of a matrix C where C = AB is what?
The determinant of a matrix A is 4. The determinant of a matrix B is 7. The determinant of a matrix C where C = AB is what?
g(x) = 7x^2 + 3x + 6. What is g(1)?
Swapping rows of a matrix multiplies its determinant by a constant factor of what?
A matrix is invertible if and only if its determinant is not equal to what?
What is the dot product of the vectors (2, 3) and (6, 2)?
What is the dot product of the vectors (0, 0) and (23, 66)?
What is the dot product of the vectors (1, 7) and (9, 4)?
What is the dot product of the vectors (8, 8) and (8, 8)?
Assuming a deck of cards has 52 cards, and 13 of each suit, what is the percentage probability that the card is either clubs or hearts?
Assuming a deck of cards has 52 cards, and 13 of each suit, what is the percentage probability that the card\'s suit is not diamonds?
What is the least common multiple of 5, 7, 11, and 13?
What is the least common multiple of 23 and 42?
What is the least common multiple of 25 and 31?
Evaluate 16 % 15.
Evaluate 27 % 11.
Evaluate 56 % 3.
How many ways can you pick 4 members of a group of 14 if order does not matter?
How many ways can you pick 7 members of a group of 12 if order does not matter?
How many ways can you pick 5 members of a group of 7 if order does not matter?
How many ways can you pick 2 members of a group of 11 if order does not matter?
How many ways can you pick 3 members of a group of 5 if order does not matter?
How many ways can you pick 9 members of a group of 10 if order does not matter?
How many possible permutations exist for the letters in the word \“MATH\”?
How many possible permutations exist for the letters in the word \“ALGEBRA\”?
How many possible permutations exist for the letters in the word \“CALCULUS\”?
How many possible permutations exist for the letters in the word \“DECIMAL\”?
A maximal planar graph has 3 vertices. How many edges must it have?
A maximal planar graph has 12 vertices. How many edges must it have?
A maximal planar graph has 17 vertices. How many edges must it have?
A maximal planar graph has 6 vertices. How many edges must it have?
A maximal planar graph has 5 vertices. How many edges must it have?
A maximal planar graph has 11 vertices. How many edges must it have?
What is the dot product of the vectors (2, 4) and (7, 3)?
What is the dot product of the vectors (9, 2) and (4, 5)?
What is the dot product of the vectors (6, 1) and (1, 2)?
What is the dot product of the vectors (4, 4) and (8, 0)?
What is the dot product of the vectors (1, 7) and (8, 2)?
A right-trangle has one __ degree angle. What number goes in the blank?
All angles in an equilateral triangle are __ degrees. What number goes in the blank?
The angles in a triangle all add up to __ degrees. What number goes in the blank?
p(x) = 2x^4 + 3x^3 + 9x + 3. What degree polynomial is p(x)?
p(x) = 9x^3 + 0. What degree polynomial is p(x)?
p(x) = 3x^8 + 7x^4 + 9x^3 + 65. What degree polynomial is p(x)?
p(x) = 45. What degree polynomial is p(x)?
p(x) = 87x^6 + 23x^5 + 9x^2 + 410. What degree polynomial is p(x)?
For a function to be considering strictly decreasing, what value must the derivative (f\'(x)) be less than?
0x005A converted from hexadecimal to decimal is:
0x000000FF converted from hexadecimal to decimal is:
0x000000A3 converted from hexadecimal to decimal is:
0x00000062 converted from hexadecimal to decimal is:
0x000000C9 converted from hexadecimal to decimal is:
0x0000006B converted from hexadecimal to decimal is:
0x0231 converted from hexadecimal to decimal is:
0x9F3F converted from hexadecimal to decimal is:
0x43AC converted from hexadecimal to decimal is:
0x0E5C converted from hexadecimal to decimal is:

Princess Trig has been captured and imprisoned by the evil Math Wizard Calcebra and needs your help. Calcebra is willing to release the princess once someone bests him in a competition of mathematics.

			You are a brave and adventurous mathematician and have been called upon by King Pythagoras to get the princess back. You have conquered every high school level math adventure known to man but this one will be a true test of your mathematical fortitude.

			As you travel to the castle you ponder the difficulty of the upcoming task and are glad that you remembered to bring your study journal in case you are ever stumped by the wicked math problems.

Princess Trig has been captured and imprisoned by the evil Math Wizard Calcebra and needs your help. Calcebra is willing to release the princess once someone bests him in a competition of mathematics.

			You are a brave and adventurous mathematician and have been called upon by King Pythagoras to get the princess back. You have conquered every high school level math adventure known to man but this one will be a true test of your mathematical fortitude.

			As you travel to the castle you ponder the difficulty of the upcoming task and are glad that you remembered to bring your study journal in case you are ever stumped by the wicked math problems.

Upon defeating Calcebra, he collapses in awe of your mathematical abilities and frees Princess Trig. He beckons you to come closer and he reveals the following:

			"I only took the princess to encourage you to learn mathematics... It makes me proud that you were able to make it this far. Please, take Princess Trig with you and teach her your mathematical knowledge. She will need it for the years to come."

			Calcebra then disappears into a plume of smoke, and you are left with Princess Trig. She blushes slightly when your eyes meet.

Welcome to Math Quest!

Math Quest is a text based, story-driven game that follows a hero\'s quest to rescue a princess from an evil math wizard\'s castle. The game starts at the entrance to the wizards\'s castle with each following level being unlocked by completing a math problem.

To progress through the game, simply click continue once you have read through the story and you will be provided with a problem to solve. If you provide a correct solution, your hero will progress to the next level, otherwise, you will lose a life.
Note: please answer all questions using only numbers
Example Question:
Convert 10100011 from binary to decimal

ABOUT
About Math Quest
Math Quest first started development in the Spring of 2017 by a group of undergraduate computing science students at Simon Fraser University.

Our goal with Math Quest is to highlight the widely differing mathematical concepts included in the pursuit of a computing science degree.\nThe music featured in this application was written by: soundcloud.com/mikhelvin/.
Thank you for downloading our game, and we sincerely hope you enjoy it.
If you have any questions or concerns, please contact as at mathquestapp@gmail.com.
